post.title: Dairy and Plant-Based Milks: Comparing Nutritional Value
post.content:encoded:
A look at soy, almond, coconut, and oat milks compared to dairy

Non-dairy milk-like beverages have been consumed for centuries in different parts of the world. However, our modern, commercial versions of these beverages are not so much concerned with trying to follow ancient culinary traditions as they are with trying to emulate cow’s milk.

While plant-based milk beverages look like cow’s milk, and may even taste a bit like it too, I was curious about how their nutritional value compares. So, I pulled the nutritional information from four of the most popular varieties of milk alternatives (soy, almond, coconut, and oat) made by Silk brand and compared them to whole milk. It seemed the best way to do was was to compare them by the percentages of the daily recommended dietary amount in a given volume. I’ll discuss that in greater detail, but first the graph:

The plant-based alternatives are similar to whole milk in terms of fat, calories, carbs, calcium, and vitamin D. But if you want something comparable in terms of protein, you’ll have to go with soy milk. Soy milk has other nutrients as well that aren’t in almond, coconut, or oat, so it seems to be the most nutritional plant-based milk. There are several vitamins and minerals in cow’s milk that aren’t in all of the plant-based options, so generally speaking, cow’s milk is the most nutritious option.

Methods and Limitations:

The nutritional value for Silk brand Soymilk, Almondmilk, Coconutmilk, and Oatmilk were taken from the Silk webpage. The nutritional value for whole milk with vitamin D added was taken from the USDA FoodData Central tables, which is based on many samples of milk from all over the U.S. So it should be noted that the nutritional content of cow’s milk and vegetable milks will definitely vary depending on where it comes from and what brand it is.

The recommendary dietary allowances (RDA) per day that the percentages are based on are taken from the U.S. National Academy of Sciences Recommended Dietary Reference Intake tables. I used the values for adults between the ages of 31 and 50, and I used the maximum value listed for men or women. So these values will vary depending on age and gender, and probably by country as well. The percentages I came up with from this are different from the percentages listed on the Silk product information. I’m not sure what their percentages are based on exactly.
